metadata.title: UK Democracy Basics
metadata.description: Fundamental concepts about democracy and the UK political system
metadata.subject: UK Politics and Democracy

questions.question: What does 'democracy' mean?
questions.explanation: Democracy comes from the Greek words 'demos' (people) and 'kratos' (power/rule). It means that the people have the power to choose their government through voting.

questions.question: At what age can you vote in UK general elections?
questions.explanation: In the UK, you must be 18 or over to vote in general elections. However, you can register to vote when you're 16 or 17 so you're ready when you turn 18.

questions.question: How often are UK general elections held?
questions.explanation: UK general elections must be held at least every 5 years, though the Prime Minister can call an election earlier.

questions.question: What is the name of the UK Parliament building?
questions.explanation: The UK Parliament meets in the Houses of Parliament (also called the Palace of Westminster) in London. It contains both the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT a key feature of democracy?
questions.explanation: Democracy requires regular elections where power can change hands. Rule by one person forever (dictatorship) is the opposite of democracy, which depends on the people's ability to choose and change their leaders.

questions.question: What is the role of MPs (Members of Parliament)?
choices: To represent their local area in Parliament
questions.explanation: MPs represent the people in their local area (constituency) in the House of Commons. They debate laws, vote on government policies, and speak up for their constituents' concerns.
